title: Chronic Migraine
scope: ** Comprehensive evaluation and management of chronic migraine in adults (defined as ≥15 headache days/month for >3 months, with migraine features on ≥8 days/month per ICHD-3). Covers preventive pharmacotherapy (oral agents, CGRP monoclonal antibodies, oral CGRP antagonists, onabotulinumtoxinA), acute treatment optimization, medication overuse headache screening and management, comorbidity assessment, and non-pharmacologic interventions. Primary focus on outpatient preventive management with acute/inpatient protocols for status migrainosus and refractory attacks. Excludes episodic migraine with <15 headache days/month (see Migraine template), cluster headache, and other trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias.

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Chronic migraine is a neurological condition that requires long-term management
Keep daily headache diary: frequency, severity, triggers, medications used (acute medication days are CRITICAL to track)
STRICTLY limit acute medication use: triptans ≤9 days/month, NSAIDs ≤14 days/month, combination analgesics ≤10 days/month
Preventive medications take 4-8 weeks to show benefit; give each an adequate trial (2-3 months at target dose)
CGRP injections are administered monthly or quarterly; most patients see improvement by month 3
Botox treatments are given every 12 weeks; minimum 2 cycles needed before assessing efficacy
Identify and avoid personal migraine triggers (e.g., certain foods, stress, weather, hormonal changes)
Return to ED if: worst headache of life, fever with headache, neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizure
Follow up with headache specialist/neurologist in 4-6 weeks for preventive initiation and q3 months thereafter
Do NOT stop preventive medications abruptly without physician guidance

Lifestyle & Non-Pharmacologic Interventi.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours); avoid oversleeping and sleep deprivation
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week; 30 min, 5 days/week); builds gradually
Stress management: cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for headache, mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), progressive muscle relaxation
Biofeedback training (thermal or EMG biofeedback; Level A evidence for migraine prevention)
Stay well-hydrated (64+ oz water daily); avoid dehydration triggers
Consistent meal schedule (avoid skipping meals); limit or avoid alcohol, aged cheese, MSG, processed meats, nitrates
Limit caffeine to consistent moderate intake (<200 mg/day); avoid abrupt caffeine withdrawal
Consider neuromodulation devices (FDA-cleared): sTMS (SpringTMS), eTNS (Cefaly), nVNS (gammaCore), REN (Nerivio)
Acupuncture (Level A evidence from Cochrane reviews; may be used adjunctively)
Yoga and tai chi (emerging evidence for headache frequency reduction)
